channel.title: NullPointers
channel.description: Could somebody tell me why I keep getting NullPointerExceptions in the stupidest places. Can somebody just summarize basically what a null is.. I always get a null when trying to do an action from and object click but handle that action in another file.. Like a boolean check for combat level, I get the nullpointer at the if statement..

item.title: NullPointers
item.dc:creator: @doom_j doom_j
item.description:
@doom_j wrote:

http://download.oracle.com/javase/6/docs/api/java/lang/NullPointerException.html

Read full topic

item.title: NullPointers
item.dc:creator: @CoonHunter CoonHunter
item.description:
@CoonHunter wrote:

Another example would be common for me when I forgot to do something.

You declared this in the class.
JButton button;

Then while forming the gui:
this.add(button, BorderLayout.CENTER);

This would throw a nullpointer if you never finished declaring the button.
button = new JButton(“hi”);

Sorry if there is a grammer mistake I’m on a phone. Anyways a nullpointer is trying to use a variable that never has a value set to it. Same thing when using a component that was never finished. Generally to get rid of that you could do.

if(button != null) {
this.add(button, BorderLayout.CENTER);
}

Would only add the button if said button does not equal null.

Read full topic

item.title: NullPointers
item.dc:creator: @Svitkona Svitkona
item.description:
@Svitkona wrote:

It’s like trying to use something that doesn’t exist

Read full topic

item.title: NullPointers
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

imsuperman05:

Could somebody tell me why I keep getting NullPointerExceptions in the stupidest places. Can somebody just summarize basically what a null is… I always get a null when trying to do an action from and object click but handle that action in another file… Like a boolean check for combat level, I get the nullpointer at the if statement…

A NullPointerException essentially means that something was null when it shouldn’t have been.

For example:

String s = null;
if (condition) {
    s = "Some string";
}
s.getLength();

The code will compile perfectly fine, but the compiler doesn’t know if condition can be reached at compile-time (for example, if the condition is based on another variable). At this point, s may or may not be null (I believe there may actually be a warning by the compiler “potential null-pointer access”); at this point, calling getLength() on an object which (essentially) doesn’t exist results in throwing the exception.

Read full topic
